sections.title: Intro Section
sections.image: Description: A vintage, classic-looking camera (like a Leica or an old SLR) is displayed prominently. The image has a nostalgic, slightly technical feel, celebrating the mechanics of photography.
sections.text: We've seen how the human eye works. Now, let's build a camera from scratch. We'll start with the simplest model possible—a concept known since antiquity—to understand the absolute core principle of image formation. This is the Pinhole Camera, and its elegant geometry is the foundation of all photography and computer vision.

sections.title: The Camera Obscura
sections.content: Imagine a completely dark room with one tiny hole in a window shade. If you look at the wall opposite the hole, you'll see a faint, upside-down image of the world outside. This is a 'camera obscura', or pinhole camera. It works because light travels in straight lines.

additionalContent.text: Only a very small number of light rays from any single point in the outside world can pass through the tiny pinhole. These rays continue in a straight line until they hit the back wall, forming a sharp, point-for-point inverted projection of the scene.
additionalContent.image: Description: A clear, simple diagram of the Pinhole Camera model (based on Figure 2.10). It shows a 3D object (a candle) on the right. Light rays from the top and bottom of the candle cross as they pass through the pinhole in the center, forming a smaller, inverted image of the candle on the 'image plane' on the left.

sections.title: The Maths of Projection
sections.content: This elegant principle can be described with some simple mathematics. Our goal is to figure out exactly where a point in the 3D world will land on our 2D image plane.

additionalContent.text: Let's set up a coordinate system. A point in the world has coordinates (X, Y, Z). The image plane is at a distance 'f' from the pinhole. This 'f' is called the **focal length**. The point on our image has coordinates (x', y'). Because the image is inverted, the relationship is based on similar triangles.

steps.stepContent: Look at the side view of our camera. We have two triangles: a large one outside the camera formed by the object's height (Y) and its distance (Z), and a small one inside the camera formed by the image height (y') and the focal length (f).
steps.stepLatex: Y \text{ and } Z \text{ (World)}, y' \text{ and } f \text{ (Image)}

steps.stepContent: These two triangles are similar, which means the ratio of their corresponding sides is equal. The height of the image (y') relative to the focal length (f) is the same as the height of the object (Y) relative to its distance (Z).
Wait! Our image is upside-down. So, the image coordinate y' is actually negative. Let's fix our equation. To make y' negative, we can write the equation like this, which is equivalent.
Now, we just solve for our image coordinates, x' and y'. We do the exact same thing for the X coordinate. This gives us the fundamental projection equations.

example.title: Example Calculation
example.problem: A camera has a focal length `f = 25mm`. You're taking a photo of a person who is 1800mm tall (Y) and standing 5000mm away (Z). How tall will their image be on the sensor (y')?
example.result: The person's image on the sensor will be 9mm tall and upside down.

sections.title: The Problem with Pinholes
sections.content:
The pinhole camera is simple and beautiful, but it has a major flaw: the trade-off between brightness and sharpness. 

- A **tiny pinhole** creates a very sharp image, but lets in very little light, so the image is incredibly dim.
- A **larger pinhole** lets in more light for a brighter image, but rays from the same point in the scene can now hit multiple spots on the image plane, creating a blurry mess.
sections.image: Description: A visual comparison (based on Figure 2.11). The left side shows a large pinhole with multiple light rays from a single point on an object spreading out to create a blurry spot on the image plane. The right side shows a lens gathering all those rays and focusing them back to a single, sharp point.

additionalContent.text: To solve this, we use a **lens**. A lens can have a large opening to gather lots of light, but it uses the principles of refraction to bend all those light rays back to a single, sharp point. This gives us the best of both worlds: a bright AND sharp image.

sections.title: Controlling the Scene: Aperture and Depth of Field
sections.content: Modern cameras with lenses have an adjustable opening called an **aperture**, which works just like the iris in your eye. But changing its size does more than just control brightness. It also controls the **Depth of Field (DoF)**—the range of distances in your scene that appear acceptably sharp.

additionalContent.text: Think of it this way: a small aperture acts more like a pinhole, forcing light to travel in straighter lines, which brings more of the scene (both near and far) into focus. A large aperture is less strict, and only the exact distance you're focused on will be perfectly sharp. Let's see this in action.
additionalContent.interactive:
Description for 'Aperture & DoF Simulator': The student sees a photographic scene with a flower in the foreground, a tree in the mid-ground, and mountains in the background. A slider is labeled 'Aperture' with settings from 'f/1.8 (Large Opening)' to 'f/22 (Small Opening)'.
- As the student moves the slider towards 'f/1.8', the flower stays sharp, but the tree and mountains become very blurry. A 'light meter' shows the scene is bright. A text label says 'Shallow Depth of Field - great for portraits!'.
- As they move the slider towards 'f/22', the flower, tree, and mountains all become sharp. The light meter shows the scene is much darker. A label says 'Deep Depth of Field - great for landscapes!'.

whyItMatters.text: The pinhole equations are the mathematical heart of all 3D-to-2D projection in computer graphics and computer vision. And understanding aperture and Depth of Field is key to both artistic photography and practical computer vision tasks where you might need the entire scene to be in focus.

buildYourVocab.definition: The simplest camera model, explaining image formation via geometric projection. It forms an inverted image.

buildYourVocab2.definition: The distance from the center of the lens (or pinhole) to the image plane. It affects the field of view.

buildYourVocab3.definition: The range of distances in a scene that appear acceptably sharp in a photograph.

frequentlyAsked.question: Does the Z-value (depth) get stored in the final image?
frequentlyAsked.answer: No, and that's a crucial point! In this projection process, all the 3D depth information from the Z coordinate is lost. The 3D world is collapsed onto a flat 2D plane. A major challenge in computer vision is trying to infer that lost depth information back from the 2D image.

testYourKnowledge.question: You want to take a landscape photo where everything from the nearby rocks to the distant mountains is sharp. What kind of aperture setting should you use?

options.explanation: A large aperture creates a shallow depth of field, which would make either the rocks or the mountains blurry. This is better for portraits.
Correct! A small aperture creates a deep depth of field, ensuring that a wide range of distances from near to far are all in focus.

options.option: The aperture size doesn't affect the sharpness of different distances.
options.explanation: It absolutely does! This is the core concept of Depth of Field.

sections.title: Review and Reflect
sections.image: Description: A triptych visual. The left panel shows the simple geometry of a pinhole camera. The center panel shows a lens focusing light. The right panel shows the DoF simulator image, illustrating the creative control of aperture.
sections.text:
Great job building our first camera! We've laid the physical and mathematical groundwork for how any camera, from the most ancient to the most modern, forms an image. Let's review:

- **Pinhole Camera:** The simplest model, forming an inverted image based on light traveling in straight lines. Its geometry is described by the **projection equations**.
- **The Role of a Lens:** Lenses solve the pinhole's brightness vs. sharpness trade-off, allowing for images that are both bright and sharp.
- **Aperture & DoF:** The aperture controls both the amount of light and the **Depth of Field**, giving photographers and roboticists control over what is in focus.

We've successfully formed a sharp, bright image on a plane. But how do we *record* it and turn it into a digital file? In the next lesson, we'll dive into the heart of the digital camera: the sensor.
